passage_text: Psalmen Davids (Psalms of David) is a collection of sacred choral music, settings mostly of psalms in German by Heinrich Schütz, who had studied the Venetian polychoral style with Giovanni Gabrieli. Book 1 was printed in Dresden in 1619 as his Opus 2. It comprises 26 individual settings, which were assigned numbers 22 to 47 in the Schütz-Werke-Verzeichnis (SWV). Most of them use the text of a complete psalm in the translation by Martin Luther.
summary_text: "Psalmen Davids" is a choral music collection by Heinrich Schütz, featuring settings of psalms in German. Influenced by the Venetian polychoral style, the first book was published in Dresden in 1619 as Opus 2 and includes 26 individual psalm settings numbered 22 to 47 in the Schütz-Werke-Verzeichnis. Most settings are based on Martin Luther's translation of the psalms.

passage_text: Henry Carwithen McQuillan (30 September 1906 – 28 April 1979) was a Progressive Conservative party member of the House of Commons of Canada. Born in Courtenay, British Columbia, he was a contractor and logger by career. He made an unsuccessful attempt to defeat CCF incumbent Thomas Speakman Barnett at the Comox—Alberni riding in the 1957 federal election. McQuillan succeeded in the 1958 election, serving in the 24th Parliament before Barnett retook the riding in the 1962 election. McQuillan also served as a school trustee at one time.

passage_text: Samatiguila Department is a department of Kabadougou Region in Denguélé District, Ivory Coast. At its creation, it was part of Denguélé Region. In 2011, districts were introduced as new first-level subdivisions of Ivory Coast. At this time, Samatiguila Department became part of Kabadougou Region in Denguélé District.
summary_text: Samatiguila Department is located in the Kabadougou Region of the Denguélé District in Ivory Coast, with a population of 17,483 as of 2014, making it the least-populous department in the country. Its administrative center is the settlement of Samatiguila, and it includes the sub-prefectures of Kimbirila-Sud and Samatiguila. Established in 2009 from a portion of Odienné Department, Samatiguila became part of Kabadougou Region during a reorganization of administrative divisions in 2011, which classified districts as first-level subdivisions and regions as second-level subdivisions, while departments were designated as third-level subdivisions.

Born in Harringay, Markall was ordained as a Catholic priest at the age of 32 in 1937 and migrated to what was then known as Rhodesia, where he was appointed Coadjutor Archbishop of Salisbury (now Harare, Zimbabwe) in 1956. He resigned 20 years later on 31 May 1976 as Archbishop of Salisbury. It lies approximately south-west of Tułowice and south-west of the regional capital Opole. Before 1945 the area was part of Germany (see "Territorial changes of Poland after World War II"). The village has a population of 280. References. <br
summary_text: Goszczowice is a village in Gmina Tułowice, Opole County, Opole Voivodeship, located in south-western Poland. It lies south-west of Tułowice and the regional capital, Opole. The village, which has a population of 280, was part of Germany before 1945.

passage_text: John Henry Kyl (May 9, 1919 – December 23, 2002) was an American politician who served as a member of the United States House of Representatives, representing Iowa's 4th congressional district from 1959 to 1965 and again from 1967 to 1973. He was a member of the Republican Party. Early life and education. Kyl was born in Wisner, Nebraska, the son of Johanna (née Boonstra) and Jon George Kyl, both Dutch immigrants. He graduated from Nebraska State Teachers College (Wayne, Nebraska) and the University of Nebraska. Career. Kyl was a teacher at Nebraska State Teachers College from 1940 to 1950.
summary_text: John Henry Kyl (1919-2002) was an American politician and Republican who represented Iowa's 4th congressional district in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1959 to 1965 and again from 1967 to 1973. Born in Wisner, Nebraska, to Dutch immigrant parents, he graduated from Nebraska State Teachers College and the University of Nebraska. Before his political career, he worked as a teacher at Nebraska State Teachers College from 1940 to 1950.

passage_text: Eleanor Crockett Pressly (1918 – May 10, 2003) was an American mathematician and aeronautical engineer in the sounding rocket program at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. Early life. Eleanor Crockett Pressly was born in Due West, South Carolina, the only child of Samuel Agnew Pressly and Georgia Crockett Pressly. She earned a bachelor's degree at Erskine College in 1938, and a master's degree in mathematics at Duke University in 1943. Career. During World War II, Pressly taught mathematics to air corps students at Winthrop College and worked at Radio Research Laboratory at Harvard University.
summary_text: Eleanor Crockett Pressly (1918 – May 10, 2003) was an American mathematician and aeronautical engineer who contributed to NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center's sounding rocket program. Born in Due West, South Carolina, she earned a bachelor's degree from Erskine College in 1938 and a master's degree in mathematics from Duke University in 1943. During World War II, Pressly taught mathematics to air corps students at Winthrop College and worked at the Radio Research Laboratory at Harvard University.

passage_text: Tułowice () is a town in Opole County, Opole Voivodeship, in south-western Poland. It is the seat of Gmina Tułowice. It lies approximately south-west of the regional capital Opole. It is located within the historic region of Upper Silesia. The town has a population of 4,011. History. In the Middle Ages the settlement was under Polish rule, and then it was also part of Bohemia (Czechia), Prussia and Germany. During World War II, the Germans established and operated the E581 forced labour subcamp of the Stalag VIII-B/344 prisoner-of-war camp in the village.
summary_text: Tułowice is a town located in Opole County, Opole Voivodeship, in south-western Poland, serving as the seat of Gmina Tułowice. It lies southwest of the regional capital, Opole, and has a population of 4,011. Historically, Tułowice was under Polish rule in the Middle Ages and later part of Bohemia, Prussia, and Germany. During World War II, it hosted a forced labor subcamp of the Stalag VIII-B/344 prisoner-of-war camp.

passage_text: James 1 is the first chapter of the Epistle of James in the New Testament of the Christian Bible. The author identifies himself as "James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ" and the epistle is traditionally attributed to James the brother of Jesus, written in Jerusalem between 48–61 CE. Alternatively, some scholars argue that it is a pseudographical work written after 61 CE. This chapter contains the letter prescript, an exposition about the joy in temptations, related to three connected actions: hearing, speaking and doing. Text and interpretation.
summary_text: James 1 is the introductory chapter of the Epistle of James, traditionally attributed to James, the brother of Jesus, and written in Jerusalem between 48–61 CE. The chapter begins with the author identifying himself and includes themes of joy in facing temptations, emphasizing the interconnected actions of hearing, speaking, and doing. Some scholars suggest the work may have been written pseudographically after 61 CE.

passage_text: He presided over the first meeting which issued in the foundation of the National Society, and subsequently lent the scheme his strong support. He also exerted himself to promote the establishment of the Indian episcopate. As Archbishop of Canterbury, Manners-Sutton appointed his cousin, Evelyn Levett Sutton, a chaplain to Lord Manners, as one of six preachers of Canterbury Cathedral in 1811. In 1819, he presided over the christening of the future Queen Victoria at Kensington Palace. He died at Lambeth on 21 July 1828, and was buried 29 July at Addington, in a family vault. Works.
summary_text: Manners-Sutton played a significant role in founding the National Society and supporting the establishment of the Indian episcopate. As Archbishop of Canterbury, he appointed his cousin as one of six preachers at Canterbury Cathedral and presided over the christening of Queen Victoria in 1819. He passed away on July 21, 1828, and was buried at Addington on July 29.
